newsitem.title: DENMARK: Danish industry ups 1997 growth forecast, cuts c/a.
newsitem.headline: Danish industry ups 1997 growth forecast, cuts c/a.

text.p: The Confederation of Danish Industries (DI) on Wednesday upgraded its forecast for 1997 GDP growth but lowered its outlook for the current account surplus.

In the latest edition of its twice-yearly outlook, DI saw 1997 GDP growth of 2.7 percent, compared to last November's forecast of 2.5 percent but cut its expectations for the current account surplus to 11 billion crowns from 12 billion.
It predicted 1997 inflation of 2.1 percent, down from its previous estimate of 2.3 percent.

For 1998 it foresaw GDP growth of 2.3 percent, down from its November estimate of 2.5 percent. It expected consumer prices to rise 2.3 percent as opposed to 2.5 percent and revised its estimate of the current account balance to 10 billion crowns from 14 billion earlier.
In a commentary to the outlook DI said that growth in other countries should to a large extent compensate for dwindling Danish shares in export markets.
"Loss of market share is expected to continue to be quite significant through to next year," it said.

"But actual international growth is expected to create such growth in demand that, despite the loss of market share, growth in industrial exports of some three percent in 1997 and 4.5 percent in 1998 is expected."
The government has pledged to eliminate the national debt and DI saw public sector spending cuts damping activity in the construction and plant industries.
But it saw GDP growth increasing private sector employment, although at a slower rate than over the past two years due to increased productivity.
